It looks like this approach involves creating a new pollset_set for each individual fd, and there may be several fds per request.  Please check with @sreecha about whether this is reasonable -- in particular, I'm not sure how much overhead is involved in creating and destroying pollset_sets.  I also seem to recall that there are some weird, counter-intuitive semantics surrounding removing pollset_sets that have been added to other pollset_sets.

If there's significant overhead, then an alternative might be to create a pollset_set in the ev driver and use that for all of the fds.  This would at least reduce the overhead to one pollset_set per request, rather than one per fd.  And I think it would eliminate the lifetime issues, since IIRC (but correct me if I'm wrong) the ev driver lives until after all of the fds are destroyed.

Just a note that in general, I think that in a common case (certainly this is the case in our tests), the ares event drivers are usually going to be one-to-one with a single fd (since more fd's are only created if a new DNS server is contact and/or TCP is used).

> If there's significant overhead, then an alternative might be to create a pollset_set in the ev driver and use that for all of the fds. This would at least reduce the overhead to one pollset_set per request, rather than one per fd. And I think it would eliminate the lifetime issues, since IIRC (but correct me if I'm wrong) the ev driver lives until after all of the fds are destroyed.

Ack this would sound good to me too.

one more option here might be to restructure things so that [the query completion](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/master/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/dns_resolver_ares.cc#L419) callback isn't invoked until the c-ares event driver (and its fd's) are destroyed, but I think that would need a more involved change.

Looking at the new integration between the request and EV driver objects, I think this is really screaming out for the two to be combined into a single object.  I won't insist upon doing that in this PR, but I think we should do that before C++-ifying this code, because it will be really hard to represent the current relationship between these objects using any of our C++ ref-counting classes.

---

Reviewed 2 of 4 files at r1, 1 of 3 files at r5, 1 of 2 files at r6, 4 of 4 files at r7.
Review status: all files reviewed, 3 unresolved discussions (waiting on @apolcyn, @dgquintas, @yihuazhang, @sreecha, and @AspirinSJL)

---

*[src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc, line 147 at r7](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/15828#-LFs9fBs2mwqeDTrUFK0:-LFs9fBs2mwqeDTrUFK1:blnjl5d) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/4b022bcd0d3c51eadf3bd8766af30c793e3cd79b/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc#L147)):*
> ```cpp
> }
> 
> static void grpc_ares_request_increment_pending_queries_locked(
> ```

I think these functions could still be called `ref` and `unref`.  The fact that the underlying type is a `size_t` instead of a `gpr_refcount` is an implementation detail; the external functionality is still the same here.

---

*[src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc, line 416 at r7](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/15828#-LFsA9qL7pnkjNDv0co2:-LFsA9qL7pnkjNDv0co3:bodtri8) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/4b022bcd0d3c51eadf3bd8766af30c793e3cd79b/src/core/ext/filters/client_channel/resolver/dns/c_ares/grpc_ares_wrapper.cc#L416)):*
> ```cpp
>   r->error = GRPC_ERROR_NONE;
>   r->pending_queries = 0;
>   error = grpc_ares_ev_driver_create_locked(&r->ev_driver, interested_parties,
> ```

Why was this moved?

This seems incorrect to me.  The `goto error_cleanup` results in us returning `nullptr`, which means that we're not returning `r`, but we are not deallocating it anywhere.  It looks like this would result in a memory leak upon error.

---

*[src/core/lib/iomgr/iomgr.h, line 39 at r7](https://reviewable.io/reviews/grpc/grpc/15828#-LFs364r7K29rk8sdRFK:-LFs364r7K29rk8sdRFL:brxq3ey) ([raw file](https://github.com/grpc/grpc/blob/4b022bcd0d3c51eadf3bd8766af30c793e3cd79b/src/core/lib/iomgr/iomgr.h#L39)):*
> ```objc
> 
> /* Exposed only for testing */
> size_t grpc_iomgr_count_objects_for_testing();
> ```

Instead of exposing this, would it be sufficient to run the test with the environment variable `GRPC_ABORT_ON_LEAKS=1`?

---
